comments.commentBody: Sorry to intervene with a little bit of truth but high taxes (marginal rates in excess of 45%) on the wealthy does indeed work in places like Germany, France and Scandinavia where even the middle class enjoys long vacations, sensible working hours, good education and excellent health care.  What would you say is "not working" in these "socialist" places?  Socialism just means a system built on the idea that decisions should be made based on the good of the society as a whole.  Why did socialism become a dirty word in American political discourse?  We must find a way to take the negative connotation out of the word socialism or find another word acceptable to the American public which means the same thing.  Without more respect for the ideas of socialism, the American political discussion becomes poorer and less understandable.

Either way is fine. In Japan, where they are a bit more facile with ohashi, most diners use them. What's important is that the soy sauce never touch the rice, but only the fish topping. Pick up with chopsticks, flip and dip, then place in the mouth with the fish touching the tongue. It's like a ballet.

If you can't manage it with chopsticks, fingers are fine so long as you don't get soy sauce on the rice.

I think if you took the time to browse the catalog of a local community college you would see the invaluable services they provide. The California JC system has always had a dual mission.  One is to provide the lower division requirements for students who are planning to transfer to a four year institution.  The other is to provide a two year AS or AA degree in a vocational subject.  For example the JC I attended had a well regarded two year program in nondestructive testing. This program had a 100% placement of its graduates.  Other vocational programs offered included welding, auto mechanics and construction trades.  Since American business typically does not invest in extensive training (unlike the Germans) these industries depend on the JC to train these workers for these good paying jobs. The local JC in my area (California wine country) supplies the training for workers in the local wine and restaurant businesses offering two year programs in viticulture and culinary arts.  The JC also offers numerous classes in computer literacy to help retrain those people that started their careers before the extensive use of computers.
It's not democratic if it's rigged.

What is the justification for thosee females' preference for non-virginity?

Modern forms of birth control have turned women into sexual objects, and all of the health risk is borne by the woman. I can understand the corresponding interest in "choice", but has the increased number of sexual partners for women worked out as "well" for them as it has for men?

Scrolling through the comments on the link was like a trip back in time. First of all, if this question (would you marry...) was posed to the unmarried, and many favored virginity for both men and women, then the respondents were themselves sexually inexperienced. Which would account, separate from culture, for some of their points of view.

Namely, that a virgin (especially a woman, but also a man) would be more likely to be faithful in marriage. Our Western view is substantially the opposite: that, absent the opportunity to experience others when young, both men and women will wonder what they have been missing and will stray.

A related Western belief is that one who is more experienced fully chooses his/her marital partner. You do not mind driving a Toyota if you have never driven a Mercedes. Having driven both, and others as well, you might very well prefer Toyota. But you choose with full knowledge of what is available.

The male preference for female virginity was first rooted in being able to determine parentage of the offspring; DNA has solved this. Now, it is the need to treat a woman as a possession instead of a person (someone else has touched your possession!), and the fear of not measuring up to other men. This last is the primary driver of virgin preference.

Why are those parents disappointed ? You fed them a constant dose of Hindi movies, took them to Indian Bazars and temples, took them to Indian restuarants etc...what did you expect ? Could it be that they do not fit into American mainstream ? Why live as a subculture in America, when you can be part of the mainstream in India ?

Don't be surprised if those kids run into culture shock in India ! Afterall. the parents raised them with the Indian culture when they left...from the 70s ! India has moved on ! In fact, young people in Indian think of Indians from America as backward !
Very nice explanation to quell any unrealistic expectations that India will relinquish this important outpost. They lost too much and learned from the past that this Siachen is not negotiable.

Having or not having sex before marriage is a very narrow definition of morality. I would place more emphasis on other sorts of behavior  as being immoral. Bride burning, aborting of girls, corruption, gender and caste discrimination as grossly immoral behavior.
If India and Pakistan become friends, then who will the US sell its weapons to?
In Mumbai,everywhere one can see pairs necking and they're mostly protected by the public.

The mythical Liberal Indian Youth rises from the ashes again. I remember a long time ago, one magazine would do an annual sex survey and would come to conclusions which would be, well, somewhat shocking in tradition-bound India.

I have never come across this liberal young generation. I am skeptical that it exists.

The big cities that we talk about so much are very much a part and parcel of the vastly bigger India. It's Indian thought and thinking that dominates.

The big city dweller is not disconnected from the other, tradition-bound India. The cellphone revolution means that there's continuous, daily contact between the two Indias.

Every evening or every night, the city dweller young man or woman makes a call to family living in the small town or village.

Going to malls or Pizza Hut or McDonalds doesn't impact one's mindset or thinking much.

The Liberal Indian Youth and the Lochness Monster live together in the Bermuda Triangle.

Nothing like trade and commerce, the intertwining of mutual interests, to shoo away the likelihood of wars among nations. It's just too darned inconvenient and costly to engage in wars given an underlying trade relationship that's widespread and robust.

This is a good development for the Indian sub-continent, and should be replicated across the globe.

Virginity has obvious advantages: the absence of sexually transmitted diseases, and the zero possibility of getting the girl pregnant.

Second, it's not as uncommon as the article seems to imply. There are millions of people (men and women) around the world who do in fact remain virgins until marriage. It could be the cultural norm, or based on religion, or following community traditions.

Third, the article makes it sound as if virginity is something of a left-over from the Victorian era or mind-set. It's not. In modern times, here in the U.S. there are plenty of young men and women who remain virgins until they get married.
That's a HUGE overstatement! Indian origin people are very unlikely to be even 20% of the workforce.

What will NASA do once all its fantastic Indian scientific staff return to India?

NASA is mostly made up of Indians, right?
Very interesting report.  Thank you.
Virgin brides used to be wanted in the West. Despite the Pope, the change is remarkable. One indian man  thinks virgin brides are faithful.  I wonder how he got that idea?.

A few years, ago, an international effort called the Kashmir Peace Partners initiative tried to propose converting the entire Siachen glacier into an international alpine park, open to high-altitude hikers and mountain-climbers and monitored by an international group. This idea has never received traction but would make much more sense than what's going on for years and years.
A good news indeed.
Indian society is called hypocritical, etc. for this attitude. US society calls it freedom or differing opinions or hih morla round maybe? Oh well!

If women actually participated in this poll, which you say they did, why do you leave them out of the article? You have said nothing about what women want (non-virgin vs virgin). Are their opinions not useful?

I was hoping this article would inform and add a new understanding to a complicated issue, but it is just confirming the obvious. Men would like to marry women who are virgins because they're scared of women having sex too freely. Men would prefer it if they were not virgins though. (Same double standard as in the US, I might add). This does show how similar socially conservative Americans are to Indian (Men), but that doesn't add anything new to the issue.
Looks like you want us to believe you know what is in the mind of each and every Indian male!!

as a deep-rooted tradition, it is not easy for the young to change the way of thinking. I think, most because of men who make sex before getting married but want to marry a virgin one, this is a paradox. I think men should change their attitude.
what the? "massive over-training of PhD scientists..." How exactly are they being overtrained and where do you propose we draw the line?
These days, it's nearly impossible to even get the funding to repeat key experiments in the literature.  You'll get filtered out for "lack of novelty" at grant review.  I know I've been there.
Quite the opposite, actually.  Academia is pretty much the opposite of a market economy.

When a prospective Professor or Department Chair has a bibliography of some 400 articles, how many of them say something worth saying? How many are fill in?  How many of them were the result of being the bottle-washer on a team?  How many break new ground? And how many are just there to impress the heck out of the search team?
